questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is admitted with fever and polyarthritis. He had a bout of streptococcal sore throat infection two weeks back. His ESR on admission was 80mm/hr and fever 39°C. What is the mechanism of tissue injury in this condition?

choices.text: Type II and type III hypersensitivity
Type II and type IV hypersensitivity

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with polyarthritis (1 major) along with fever and ESR elevated (2 minor) is suggestive of acute rheumatic fever. It is an example of type II hypersensitivity.

This condition classically occurs a few weeks after an episode of group A streptococcal pharyngitis or, less commonly, skin infections. The antibodies to streptococcal cell-wall antigen cross-react with myocardial antigen resulting in macrophage activation and inflammation.

Acute rheumatic carditis is a common manifestation of active RF and may progress over time to chronic rheumatic heart disease (RHD), mainly manifesting as valvular abnormalities. Damage to heart tissue may be caused by a combination of antibody and T-cell-mediated reactions.

Related Pearl: Types of Type II Antibody-Mediated Hypersentivity

There are 3 mechanisms involved in type 2 hypersensitivity reactions- 

  1. Antibody-mediated cellular dysfunction- antibodies react with antigens present on cell surfaces or in the extracellular matrix cause disease by destroying these cells, triggering inflammation, or interfering with normal functions
    1. Myasthenia gravis (against acetylcholine receptor)
    2. Graves’ disease (against TSH receptor)
    3. Pemphigus Vulgaris (against epidermal cadherin)
    4. Pernicious anemia (against intrinsic factor)
    5. Insulin resistant diabetes (against insulin receptor
  2. Antibody-mediated opsonization and phagocytosis -antibodies may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating complement and Recruiting Phagocytes
    1. Transfusion reactions
    2. Erythroblastosis fetalis
    3. Autoimmune hemolytic anemia
    4. Autoimmune thrombocytopenic purpura
  3. Complement and Fc receptor-mediated inflammation- antibodies may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating complement
    1. Goodpasture syndrome
    2. Vasculitis due to ANCA
    3. Acute rheumatic fever
    4. Vascular rejection in organ graft

questions.text: Which is the least commonly affected heart valve in acute rheumatic fever?
questions.solution:
The least commonly affected valve in acute rheumatic fever is the pulmonary valve.

The most commonly affected valve is the mitral valve.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman died due to cardiac failure. On autopsy, on the mitral valve, small warty vegetations were present along the lines of closure. There were also irregular thickenings in the left atrium. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the gross findings seen are diagnostic of rheumatic heart disease.

Inflammation of the endocardium and the left-sided valves results in fibrinoid necrosis within the cusps or tendinous cords. Overlying these necrotic foci and along the lines of closure are small (1 to 2  mm) warty vegetations.

Subendocardial lesions, exacerbated by regurgitant jets, can induce irregular thickenings called MacCallum plaques, usually in the left atrium.

questions.text: In a town where the prevalence of all-age rheumatic heart disease is 5 per 1000 per year, all of the following are included as major Jones criteria except:
questions.solution:
Monoarthralgia is a minor Jones criterion in moderate-high risk population (all-age rheumatic heart disease prevalence of >1 per 1000 population per year).

Major criteria for acute rheumatic fever include the following:

Criteria Characteristics
Carditis
  • Most commonly affected valve - Mitral valve
    • Acute RHD - MR
    • Chronic RHD - MS 
  • Least common - Pulmonary valve
  • Pancarditis, bread and butter pericarditis
Migratory Polyarthritis
  • Most common manifestation
  • Affects large joints, involves one joint after the other
  • Non-erosive arthritis
  • No residual deformity
  • Improves rapidly with aspirin
Subcutaneous nodules
  • Painless nodules
  • On extensor surfaces of elbows, shin, and occiput
Erythema marginatum
  • Red macular rash that spares the face
  • No residual scarring
Sydenham's chorea
  • Late manifestation
  • Involuntary purposeless movements
  • Associated with emotional lability and depression

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presents with severe dyspnoea. Mitral stenosis with left atrial hypertrophy is seen. Vegetations present on the mitral valve were excised. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the given HPE image?
questions.solution:
The given image depicts Aschoff's body, which is suggestive of rheumatic valvular disease.

Aschoff's bodies have the following components:

  • Anitschkow cells or plump macrophages 
    • Abundant cytoplasm
    • Caterpillar cells - refer to centrally condensed chromatin into slender, wavy ribbons
  • Foci of fibrinoid necrosis 
  • Aschoff's giant cells - multinucleated larger macrophages 
  • T-cells
  • Plasma cells

questions.text: A 47-year-old female patient with a long-standing history of rheumatic heart disease was admitted to hospital due to severe breathlessness. She died on the 3rd day following admission. The mitral valve shows the following findings on autopsy. What is the cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
The given image is of mitral stenosis showing fish mouth or buttonhole appearance in rheumatic heart disease. It is due to calcification and fibrosis.

Rheumatic heart disease is also associated with subendocardial irregular thickenings known as McCallum plaques, as shown below.

questions.text: Which of the following is implicated in acute infective endocarditis?
questions.solution:
Acute infective endocarditis is due to infection by highly virulent organisms like Staphylococcus aureus. It results in rapidly necrotizing and destructive lesions.

Infective endocarditis is classified into acute and subacute forms.

  • Acute - infection of a previously normal heart valve by a highly virulent organism
  • Subacute - infection in previously deformed valves by organisms of lower virulence (S.viridans, S. epidermidis, HACEK)

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with severe rheumatic mitral stenosis underwent prosthetic mitral valve insertion. In the first 2 months following surgery, he is at the highest risk of infection with which of the following organisms?
questions.solution:
Staphylococcus aureus and coagulase-negative Staphylococci (like S. epidermidis).

The following organisms are implicated in infective endocarditis following prosthetic valve surgery:

  • Early (< 2 months) - Staphylococcus aureus, Staphylococcus epidermidis
  • Intermediate (2-12 months) and late (> 12 months):
    • Streptococci and Staphylococcus aureus - more common 
    • Enterococci and Staphylococcus epidermidis

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presented with a high-grade fever, chills, and breathlessness for 4 days. He has no other known medical conditions but has a history of IV drug abuse. On examination, the following painful lesions were noted and a regurgitant murmur was heard on auscultation. All of the following are minor criteria for diagnosis of this condition except:
questions.solution:
The given features and the image showing painful Osler nodes are suggestive of infective endocarditis. Echo showing a valve-related mass is a major criterion according to Duke’s criteria.

Infective endocarditis (IE) is a microbial infection of the heart valves or the mural endocardium. The aorta, aneurysms, other blood vessels, and prosthetic devices can also become infected. Most infections are bacterial. 

Vegetations on heart valves are the classic hallmark of IE. They are friable, bulky, potentially destructive lesions. They contain fibrin, inflammatory cells, bacteria, or other organisms. The mitral valve is most commonly involved. 

Complications of infective endocarditis:

  • Cardiac complications - valvular insufficiency or stenosis, myocardial ring abscess, suppurative pericarditis
  • Embolic complications - left-sided (brain, spleen, kidney) or right-sided lesion (lung infarct and abscess)
  • Renal complications - embolic infarcts, focal (more common) or diffuse glomerulonephritis (less common) 

Related Pearl: Modified Duke's criteria for diagnosis of infective endocarditis

Diagnosis of Infective endocarditis is by Duke's Criteria, which requires either:

  1. Pathologic criteria
  2. Clinical criteria

If clinical criteria are used, definitive endocarditis is defined by the presence of 2 major or 1 major + 3 minor or 5 minor criteria.

The presence of single pathological criteria is definitive of infective endocarditis.

Note: The diagnosis of endocarditis is rejected if an alternative diagnosis is established either when:

  • Symptoms resolve and do not recur with <4 days of antibiotic therapy OR
  • If surgery or autopsy yields no pathologic or macroscopic evidence of endocarditis in <4 days of antimicrobial therapy.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presented with chest pain and breathlessness for 1 month. Examination revealed a regurgitant murmur. Transesophageal echocardiography revealed vegetations on both sides of mitral valve leaflets. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with vegetations on both sides of valve leaflets is suggestive of Libman–Sacks endocarditis. It is a feature of systemic lupus erythematosus.

The vegetations in this condition have the following features: 

  • Small - 1 to 4 mm in diameter
  • Single or multiple
  • Sterile, pinkish vegetations
  • May be located on both sides valve leaflets
  • Associated with intense valvulitis - characterized by fibrinoid necrosis 

Mitral valve is more frequently involved and regurgitation is the usual functional abnormality.

questions.text: Large, friable, irregular vegetations on heart valves are seen in which condition?
questions.solution:
Large, friable, irregular vegetations on heart valves are seen in infective endocarditis.

Infective endocarditis is characterized by the presence of large, friable, irregular vegetations on heart valves. Aortic and mitral valves are the most commonly affected, however, in some cases, the right heart valves may be involved.

Vegetations may be single or multiple and may involve one or more valves. Embolization often occurs and may lead to septic infarcts or mycotic aneurysms at the site of lodgement due to the presence of virulent organisms in the emboli.

questions.text:
Match the following morphology of vegetations with the conditions in which they are found.
  1. Rheumatic heart disease (RHD)
  2. Infective endocarditis (IE)
  3. Nonbacterial thrombotic endocarditis
  4. Libman-Sacks endocarditis
questions.solution:
The rightly matched vegetations with the conditions that they are seen are as follows: 1-C, 2-A, 3-D, 4-B

Rheumatic heart disease often presents with rheumatic fever phase where small, warty 1- 2 mm vegetations, also called veruccae, extend along the lines of closure of the valve leaflets. The cardinal anatomical changes of the mitral valve in chronic RHD are:

  • Leaflet thickening
  • Commissural fusion and shortening
  • Thickening and fusion of the tendinous chords

Infective endocarditis has large, irregular, friable masses on the valve cusps that can extend onto the chordae. These vegetations can be single or multiple and may involve one or more valves. They are potentially destructive lesions and contain fibrin, inflammatory cells, bacteria or other organisms. They can erode into the underlying myocardium and produce a ring abscess. They are prone to embolisations, resulting in abscess formation wherever they lodge due to the presence of virulent organisms. Thus, it may lead to sequelae like septic infarcts or mycotic aneurysms.

Subacute infective endocarditis contains less destructive vegetations. They contain granulation tissue at their bases indicative of healing. Fibrosis, calcification and a chronic inflammatory infiltrate can develop over the time.

Nonbacterial thrombotic endocarditis is characterised by one or more small, 1-5 mm, sterile vegetations which are usually attached at the line of closure. They are seen associated with hypercoagulable states like chronic DIC or malignancy. They are loosely attached to the underlying valve and are non-destructive in nature. They do not cause any inflammatory reaction but they can be a source of systemic embolisation.

Libman-Sack's endocarditis has small- or medium-sized, 1- 4 mm, sterile vegetations associated with systemic lupus erythematosus. They may be present on one or both the sides of the leaflets, on the valve surface, chordae or anywhere on the endocardium. These vegetations develop due to immune complex deposition and complement activation. They cause intense valvulitis resulting in fibrinoid necrosis of the valve substance. Persistent injury to the valves can result in scarring and leaflet fusion.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about non-bacterial thrombotic endocarditis?
questions.solution:
Vegetations in non-bacterial thrombotic endocarditis (NBTE) are of 1 to 5 mm size.

NBTE is seen in patients with debilitating conditions such as cancer and sepsis or systemic hypercoagulable states. Hence it is also called marantic endocarditis.

There is the deposition of small sterile thrombi loosely attached to the leaflets of cardiac valves. They form single or multiple vegetations along the lines of closure of the leaflets or cusps. They are non-invasive and do not elicit an inflammatory reaction. It can be a source of systemic emboli.
